pros: everyone is incredibly helpful Manager is patient
cons: a massive workload not many growth opportunities

pros: Constant support and understanding and a positive work environment
cons: None can't complaint about anything as the work place is amazing

pros: Great culture and staff. Workload is manageable
cons: Not much guidance, and support for this role.

job_title: Charity Shop Volunteer in Bolton, England
pros: Gained a lot of customer service experience and the manager and other volunteers were friendly.
cons: Depended on the manager - some were really good but others didn't give you much direction.

review_title: Help the store to give away clothes and accessories for the sake of raising money for charity
pros: Good workplace, polite co-workers and mostly no issues with store and its customers
cons: No pay so I didnt really see it as a long term commitment

pros:
Great work and support
Rewarding goals and objectives
Friendly work environment
cons: The workload can be stressful

review_title: Top of the Muslim Charity Sector
pros: No problems with being a Muslim at work, easy going staff environment, biggest and most professional charity in the Muslim charity sector
cons: Limited career advancement opportunities, payscales are on the lower side of the sector

review_title: Islamic Relief Worldwide (HAD) - very unprofessional organisation
job_title: Head of Research and Development in Birmingham, England
pros: Incompetent, absolutely awful and unprofessional! There were various groups and factions all with different agendas. Most very unfaithfully claiming to adhere to the noble Islamic values.
cons: It was like working at the heart of a corrupt Third-World Country. Very little gets done, very slow! The organisation is paralyzed by internal politics and incompetence.

review_title: Culturally friendly, but ultimately dysfunctional and toxic
pros:
Very islamic and culturally friendly environment 
Understanding and flexible manager 
Hardworking and dedicated field staff
cons:
- Very discouraging to work for an organisation that could do so much, but prefer to appeal to the uninformed donors
- management is poor. The people at the very top don’t know what they’re doing or where they’re going. the organisation lacks direction and identity. 
- no upwards opportunity, especially for women. There are no female directors and only one female in semi senior position in the organisation. There’s a lot of misogyny and policing of women’s dress and behaviour. 
- nepotism and corruption runs deep.

pros: Easy, enjoyable job, hard working and easy
cons: Nothing to fault in the business

pros: Good helpful team, good benefits
cons: Under resourced, no clear path for progression

pros: Excellent Organization to work for
cons: There are no cons that I can mention.

pros: Islamic environment and can make the role your own
cons: Strategy and too many processes can hinder project delivery.

job_title: Head of Programmes in London, England
pros: Young dedicated staff; positive atmosphere

review_title: Get in, get out, move on
pros: Free parking and made some good friends
cons: Very biased and poor culture

pros: Kind and friendly colleagues. Good place to work for (some) ethnic minorities, gave me an insight into what kind of org I DON'T want to work for :)
cons: Not wheelchair accessible, backward cultural norms and views, incredibly backward on gender particularly. Unprofessional working environment, due to most people being employed as a result of being someone's family friend or relative rather than on merit. Large proportion of the workforce have been there 10+ years (usually the relatives and family friends). It does not feel like you're in the 21st century. Career progression only available if you're pakistani and/or conservative muslim. Lots of unqualified staff

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros:
Fantastic family atmosphere.  People do care about the work and support each other.
Lots of different work, quite easy to move around.
If they like you (i.e. if you work well), they will look after you (find you roles)
cons:
Long hours
Work should be more organised and planned
Pay for senior managers is below what it should be

review_title: Inspirational, with great mission, but basic and undeveloped
job_title: Head of L&D in Birmingham, England
pros: Enlightened new CEO; the mission;  most of us work hard but still have lots of fun; values are prominent and (mostly) live by; with some severe exceptions, managers are supportive, appreciative and good to work for;  lots of good people doing great work.
cons: Undeveloped, basic systems, some dreadful management attitudes and practices.

pros: Brilliant atmosphere within the office (London); staff extremely friendly and really pleasant to work with
cons: Can become long hours at times, and non-stop during peak season and emergencies (but then again, that's what would happen in an international relief organisation...)

pros: extremely friendly people, very passionate environment, lots of support for all the work
cons: can be over loaded with work from time to time

job_title: Digital Marketing Officer in London, England
pros:
Working for a good cause
Good team
Room for growth
cons:
Not competitive enough salary
Need better benefits
Clearer organisational strategy required
